hierarchy.entry_domain: Third-Party and Supply Chain Asset Management

active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the implications of the SolarWinds supply chain attack: How does it demonstrate failures in due diligence? What policy changes should organizations implement to prevent similar incidents, and how do they balance cost with security? Reference NIST frameworks and voter-suggested examples like MOVEit.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in (ISC)² domains. Topic: Supply Chain Due Diligence (Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Asset Security > Information and Asset Handling > Third-Party and Supply Chain Asset Management > Supply Chain Risk Management > Supply Chain Due Diligence). Voter consensus: 82.9% approval, priorities: completeness (NIST SP 1326 full: acquirer research on suppliers), pedagogy (Bloom's progression), scaffolding (4 layers), real-world (SolarWinds, NotPetya, MOVEit), best practices/pitfalls. Incorporate: - Learning Objectives: [PASTE learning_objectives array here] - Active Learning: Use for context (e.g., flashcards spark discussions like SolarWinds debate). - Scaffolding: [PASTE scaffolding_layers here] – Ensure even coverage. Generate 24 flashcards in JSON array of objects following EXACT schema: [PASTE flashcard_generation_schema.structure here]. Adhere to distractor protocol. Align each to one objective/Bloom's level/layer. Sources: NIST SP 800-161 r1 (C-SCRM), SP 1305 (SCRM), SP 1326 IPD (due diligence); csrc.nist.gov links. Output ONLY the JSON array, no extras.
